The **Red River** , or sometimes the **Red River of the South** , is a major
river in the southern [United States of America](/wiki/United_States "United
States").[2] The river was named for the [red-bed country](/wiki/Red_beds "Red
beds") of its [watershed](/wiki/Drainage_basin "Drainage basin"). It is one of
[several rivers with that name](/wiki/Red_River_\(disambiguation\) "Red River
\(disambiguation\)"). Although it was once a tributary of the [Mississippi
River](/wiki/Mississippi_River "Mississippi River"), the Red River is now a
tributary of the [Atchafalaya River](/wiki/Atchafalaya_River "Atchafalaya
River"), a [distributary](/wiki/Distributary "Distributary") of the
Mississippi that flows separately into the Gulf of Mexico. It is connected to
the Mississippi River by the [Old River Control
Structure](/wiki/Old_River_Control_Structure "Old River Control Structure").

The south bank of the Red River formed part of the [US-Mexico
border](/wiki/US-Mexico_border "US-Mexico border") from the [Adams-Onís
Treaty](/wiki/Adams-On%C3%ADs_Treaty "Adams-Onís Treaty") (in force 1821)
until the [Texas Annexation](/wiki/Texas_Annexation "Texas Annexation") and
the [Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo](/wiki/Treaty_of_Guadalupe_Hidalgo "Treaty of
Guadalupe Hidalgo").

The Red River is the second-largest river basin in the southern [Great
Plains](/wiki/Great_Plains "Great Plains").[3] It rises in two branches in the
[Texas Panhandle](/wiki/Texas_Panhandle "Texas Panhandle") and flows east,
where it acts as the border between the states of [Texas](/wiki/Texas "Texas")
and [Oklahoma](/wiki/Oklahoma "Oklahoma"). It forms a short border between
Texas and [Arkansas](/wiki/Arkansas "Arkansas") before entering Arkansas,
turning south near [Fulton, Arkansas](/wiki/Fulton,_Arkansas "Fulton,
Arkansas"), and flowing into [Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana "Louisiana"), where
it flows into the Atchafalaya River. The total length of the river is 1,360
miles (2,190 km), with a mean flow of over 57,000 cubic feet per second (1,600
m3/s) at the mouth.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

##
Geography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red_River_of_the_South&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Geography")]

###
Course[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red_River_of_the_South&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Course")]

The Red River rises near the edge of the northwestern [dip
slope](/wiki/Dip_slope "Dip slope") of the [Llano
Estacado](/wiki/Llano_Estacado "Llano Estacado") mesa[4] in two forks in
northern [Texas](/wiki/Texas "Texas") and southwestern
[Oklahoma](/wiki/Oklahoma "Oklahoma"). The [North Fork Red
River](/wiki/North_Fork_Red_River "North Fork Red River") meets the southern
and largest fork near the Texas-Oklahoma border. The southern fork, which is
about 120 miles (190 km) long, is generally called the [Prairie Dog Town
Fork](/wiki/Prairie_Dog_Town_Fork_Red_River "Prairie Dog Town Fork Red
River"). It is formed in [Randall County, Texas](/wiki/Randall_County,_Texas
"Randall County, Texas"), near the [county seat](/wiki/County_seat "County
seat") of [Canyon](/wiki/Canyon,_Texas "Canyon, Texas"), by the
[confluence](/wiki/Confluence "Confluence") of intermittent [Palo Duro
Creek](/wiki/Palo_Duro_Creek "Palo Duro Creek") and [Tierra Blanca
Creek](/wiki/Tierra_Blanca_Creek "Tierra Blanca Creek"). (The names mean "Hard
Wood" and "White Land", respectively, in [Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_\(language\)
"Spanish \(language\)").)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/78redriver.jpg/240px-78redriver.jpg)](/wiki/File:78redriver.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:78redriver.jpg "Enlarge")

[State Highway No. 78 Bridge at the Red
River](/wiki/State_Highway_No._78_Bridge_at_the_Red_River "State Highway No.
78 Bridge at the Red River") between Oklahoma and Texas, photographed on the
Oklahoma side

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/HPIM2184.JPG/240px-
HPIM2184.JPG)](/wiki/File:HPIM2184.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:HPIM2184.JPG "Enlarge")

Crossing the Red River at the [Texas](/wiki/Texas
"Texas")-[Oklahoma](/wiki/Oklahoma "Oklahoma") border from [I-35](/wiki/I-35
"I-35")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Cane_River_Lake_of_the_Red_River%2C_Natchitoches%2C_LA_IMG_1914.JPG/240px-
Cane_River_Lake_of_the_Red_River%2C_Natchitoches%2C_LA_IMG_1914.JPG)](/wiki/File:Cane_River_Lake_of_the_Red_River,_Natchitoches,_LA_IMG_1914.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Cane_River_Lake_of_the_Red_River,_Natchitoches,_LA_IMG_1914.JPG
"Enlarge")

The Red River took a new channel near
[Natchitoches](/wiki/Natchitoches,_Louisiana "Natchitoches, Louisiana"),
[Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana "Louisiana"), and left behind [Cane River
Lake](/wiki/Cane_River "Cane River").

The Red River turns and flows southeast through [Palo Duro
Canyon](/wiki/Palo_Duro_Canyon "Palo Duro Canyon") in Palo Duro Canyon State
Park at an elevation of 3,440 feet (1,050 m),[3] then past [Newlin,
Texas](/wiki/Newlin,_Texas "Newlin, Texas"), to meet the Oklahoma state line.
Past that point, it is generally considered the main stem of the Red River.
Near [Elmer, Oklahoma](/wiki/Elmer,_Oklahoma "Elmer, Oklahoma"), the [North
Fork](/wiki/North_Fork_Red_River "North Fork Red River") finally joins, and
the river proceeds to follow a winding course east through one of the most
arid parts of the [Great Plains](/wiki/Great_Plains "Great Plains"), receiving
the [Wichita River](/wiki/Wichita_River "Wichita River") as it passes the city
of [Wichita Falls](/wiki/Wichita_Falls,_Texas "Wichita Falls, Texas"). Near
[Denison](/wiki/Denison,_Texas "Denison, Texas"), the river exits the eastern
end of [Lake Texoma](/wiki/Lake_Texoma "Lake Texoma"), a reservoir formed by
the [Denison Dam](/wiki/Denison_Dam "Denison Dam"). The lake is also fed by
the [Washita River](/wiki/Washita_River "Washita River") from the north.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/RedRiverMeandersArkansas1.jpg/220px-
RedRiverMeandersArkansas1.jpg)](/wiki/File:RedRiverMeandersArkansas1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:RedRiverMeandersArkansas1.jpg "Enlarge")

Point bars, abandoned meander loops, [oxbow lakes](/wiki/Oxbow_lake "Oxbow
lake") in Lafayette and Miller counties, Arkansas

After the river flows out of the southeastern end of the lake, it runs
generally east towards [Arkansas](/wiki/Arkansas "Arkansas") and receives
[Muddy Boggy Creek](/wiki/Muddy_Boggy_Creek "Muddy Boggy Creek") before
turning southward near [Texarkana](/wiki/Texarkana,_Arkansas "Texarkana,
Arkansas").

Soon after, the river crosses south into [Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana
"Louisiana"). The sister cities of [Shreveport](/wiki/Shreveport,_Louisiana
"Shreveport, Louisiana") and [Bossier City](/wiki/Bossier_City "Bossier City")
were developed on either bank of the river, as were the downriver cities of
[Alexandria](/wiki/Alexandria,_Louisiana "Alexandria, Louisiana") and
[Pineville](/wiki/Pineville,_Louisiana "Pineville, Louisiana"). Where it is
joined by the [Ouachita River](/wiki/Ouachita_River "Ouachita River"), its
largest tributary, the river later broadens into a complex network of
marshlands surrounding the Mississippi and
[Atchafalaya](/wiki/Atchafalaya_River "Atchafalaya River") rivers. Its waters
eventually discharge into the Atchafalaya River[5] and flow eastward or
southward into the [Gulf of Mexico](/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico "Gulf of Mexico").

In 1946, the Red River flood spilled over into Pineville because of
insufficient levee height and strength. However, the taller and stronger levee
held in Alexandria. Willie E. Kees Jr., the newly elected mayor of Pineville,
worked to gain support for the Corps of Engineers to increase the height of
the levee on the eastern side of the river to equal that in Alexandria.[6]

###
Tributaries[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red_River_of_the_South&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Tributaries")]

Tributaries include the [Little Red River](/wiki/Little_Red_River_\(Texas\)
"Little Red River \(Texas\)"), [Prairie Dog Town Fork Red
River](/wiki/Prairie_Dog_Town_Fork_Red_River "Prairie Dog Town Fork Red
River"), [Salt Fork Red River](/wiki/Salt_Fork_Red_River "Salt Fork Red
River"), [North Fork Red River](/wiki/North_Fork_Red_River "North Fork Red
River"), [Pease River](/wiki/Pease_River "Pease River"), [Washita
River](/wiki/Washita_River "Washita River"), [Kiamichi
River](/wiki/Kiamichi_River "Kiamichi River"), [Little Wichita
River](/wiki/Little_Wichita_River "Little Wichita River"), [Little
River](/wiki/Little_River_\(Red_River\) "Little River \(Red River\)"),
[Sulphur River](/wiki/Sulphur_River "Sulphur River"), [Loggy
Bayou](/wiki/Loggy_Bayou "Loggy Bayou") (through [Lake
Bistineau](/wiki/Lake_Bistineau "Lake Bistineau") and [Dorcheat
Bayou](/wiki/Dorcheat_Bayou "Dorcheat Bayou")) as well as the [Ouachita
River](/wiki/Ouachita_River "Ouachita River") (also known as the Black River
at that point) not far (at [Acme, Louisiana](/wiki/Acme,_Louisiana "Acme,
Louisiana")) from the mouth.

##
Watershed[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red_River_of_the_South&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Watershed")]

The Red River's watershed covers 65,590 square miles (169,900 km2)[3] and is
the southernmost major river system in the [Great Plains](/wiki/Great_Plains
"Great Plains"). Its drainage basin is mostly in the states of Texas and
Oklahoma, but also covers parts of Arkansas and Louisiana. Its basin is
characterized by flat, fertile [agricultural](/wiki/Agricultural
"Agricultural") land, with only a few major cities. The drainage basin of the
Red River is very arid and receives little
[precipitation](/wiki/Precipitation_\(meteorology\) "Precipitation
\(meteorology\)"). As a result, much of the river above the Texas-Oklahoma
border is intermittent, and until the river is past its great bend south in
Arkansas, the flow varies widely. Most of the agriculture in the basin is
sustained by [groundwater](/wiki/Groundwater "Groundwater"), which is
recharged with rainfall and riverflow. The lower course of the river flows
through a series of [marshes](/wiki/Marsh "Marsh") and [swamps](/wiki/Swamp
"Swamp"), where its flow is dramatically moderated.

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red_River_of_the_South&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: History")]

### Native
Americans[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red_River_of_the_South&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Native Americans")]

Native American cultures along the river were diverse, developing specialized
adaptations to the many different environments.[3] By the time of
[European](/wiki/Europe "Europe") contact, the eastern [Piney
Woods](/wiki/Piney_Woods "Piney Woods") were dominated by the numerous
historic tribes of the [Caddoan](/wiki/Caddoan "Caddoan") Confederacy. They
found plentiful game and fish, and also had good land for cultivating staple
crops.[3] The middle part of the Red River was dominated by
[Wichita](/wiki/Wichita_people "Wichita people") and [Tonkawa](/wiki/Tonkawa
"Tonkawa"). This area was [prairie](/wiki/Prairie "Prairie"), where Native
Americans constructed portable and temporary [tepees](/wiki/Tepee "Tepee") for
housing. They practiced limited farming and followed game in seasonal,
[nomadic](/wiki/Nomadic "Nomadic") hunting cycles.[3] The Plains division of
the [Lipan Apache](/wiki/Lipan_Apache_people "Lipan Apache people") dominated
the western Red River area until the 18th century, when they were displaced by
invading [Comanche](/wiki/Comanche "Comanche") from the north.[3]

### European-American exploration and
settlement[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red_River_of_the_South&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: European-American exploration and settlement")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Theb0771_-_Flickr_-
_NOAA_Photo_Library.jpg/220px-Theb0771_-_Flickr_-
_NOAA_Photo_Library.jpg)](/wiki/File:Theb0771_-_Flickr_-
_NOAA_Photo_Library.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Theb0771_-_Flickr_-_NOAA_Photo_Library.jpg "Enlarge")

Crossing the Red River near [Granite, Oklahoma](/wiki/Granite,_Oklahoma
"Granite, Oklahoma"), 1921.

In 1806, President [Thomas Jefferson](/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson "Thomas
Jefferson") commissioned the [Red River
Expedition](/wiki/Red_River_Expedition_\(1806\) "Red River Expedition
\(1806\)") to explore parts of the new lands of the [Louisiana
Purchase](/wiki/Louisiana_Purchase "Louisiana Purchase") by traveling up the
Red River. He said it was "in truth, next to the Missouri, the most
interesting water of the Mississippi", in a letter to [William
Dunbar](/wiki/William_Dunbar "William Dunbar").[7] Having threaded the maze of
[bayous](/wiki/Bayous "Bayous") at the river's confluence, and the "[Great
Raft](/wiki/Great_Raft "Great Raft")" of lodged driftwood, the expedition, was
stopped by the [Spanish](/wiki/Colonial_Mexico "Colonial Mexico") near what is
now [New Boston, Texas](/wiki/New_Boston,_Texas "New Boston, Texas").

In 1806, Lieutenant [Zebulon Pike](/wiki/Zebulon_Pike "Zebulon Pike"), under
orders to ascertain the source of the Red River, ascended the [Arkansas
River](/wiki/Arkansas_River "Arkansas River"), made his way downstream on what
turned out to be the [Rio Grande](/wiki/Rio_Grande "Rio Grande"), and was sent
home by the Spanish authorities. A more successful exploration of the river's
upper reaches to both its sources was the 1852 expedition under Capt.
[Randolph Barnes Marcy](/wiki/Randolph_Barnes_Marcy "Randolph Barnes Marcy"),
assisted by Brevet Capt. [George B. McClellan](/wiki/George_B._McClellan
"George B. McClellan").[8] The latter was important as a general in the
[American Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American Civil War").

In April 1815, Captain Henry Miller Shreve was the first person to bring a
steamboat, the _Enterprise_ , up the Red River. Fulton and Livingston, who
claimed the exclusive right to navigate Louisiana waters by steamboat, sued
Shreve in the District Court of New Orleans. The judge ruled that the monopoly
claimed by the plaintiffs was illegal. That decision, along with a similar
outcome in _Gibbons v. Ogden_ freed navigation on every river, lake or harbor
in the United States from interference by monopolies.[9]

When John Quincy Adams became Secretary of State in 1817, one of his highest
priorities was to negotiate the boundaries of the Louisiana Purchase with
Spain. He negotiated with the Spanish Minister to the United States, [Luis de
Onis](/wiki/Luis_de_Onis "Luis de Onis"), and finally concluded [Adams-Onis
Treaty](/wiki/Adams-Onis_Treaty "Adams-Onis Treaty"), also known as the Treaty
of 1819. The treaty defined the south bank of the river as the boundary
between the United States and Spain. That boundary continued to be recognized
when Mexico gained its independence from Spain, then again when Texas became
independent from Mexico. It remained so [9] until the United States Congress
consented to the Red River Boundary Compact adopted by the states of Oklahoma
and Texas, which set the jurisdictional boundary between Texas and Oklahoma at
the vegetation line on the south bank, but left title of adjacent property
owners at the south bank.

In Louisiana, the area of present-day [Natchitoches
Parish](/wiki/Natchitoches_Parish "Natchitoches Parish") was settled by French
Creole and mixed-race [Louisiana Creole people](/wiki/Louisiana_Creole_people
"Louisiana Creole people"), starting before 1800. The [Cane River National
Heritage Area](/wiki/Cane_River_National_Heritage_Area "Cane River National
Heritage Area") marks this area of influence, with
[plantations](/wiki/Plantations_in_the_American_South "Plantations in the
American South") and churches founded by Louisiana Creoles. Some of the sites
are designated as destinations on the [Louisiana African American Heritage
Trail](/wiki/Louisiana_African_American_Heritage_Trail "Louisiana African
American Heritage Trail"), designed in the 21st century. For nearly 100 years
after the [American Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American Civil War"),
some of the plantations were the center of a large [African
American](/wiki/African_American "African American") and Creole community
life, whose people lived and worked in this area for generations.

The area along the lower Red River of [Grant Parish,
Louisiana](/wiki/Grant_Parish,_Louisiana "Grant Parish, Louisiana"), and
neighboring parishes were a mixture of hill country and cotton plantations,
with white [planters](/wiki/Planter_\(American_South\) "Planter \(American
South\)") and subsistence farmers, and numerous African American
[slaves](/wiki/Slaves "Slaves") working the plantations in the _ante bellum_
years. It was an area of heated social tensions and
[insurgency](/wiki/Insurgency "Insurgency") during and after the
[Reconstruction era](/wiki/Reconstruction_era_\(United_States\)
"Reconstruction era \(United States\)"). Grant was a new parish created by the
Reconstruction legislature, which was trying to increase [Republican
Party](/wiki/Republican_Party_\(United_States\) "Republican Party \(United
States\)") representation. In 1873, Grant Parish was the site of the [Colfax
massacre](/wiki/Colfax_massacre "Colfax massacre"), caused by the political
tension and violence arising from the disputed 1872 gubernatorial election and
efforts by local whites to keep white supremacy. White
[militias](/wiki/Militias "Militias"), organized from nearby parishes, killed
more than 100 freedmen, some of whom had surrendered as prisoners.

In 1874, such militias organized as the [White League](/wiki/White_League
"White League") in Grant Parish, and other chapters were soon founded across
the state. The [Coushatta Massacre](/wiki/Coushatta_Massacre "Coushatta
Massacre") was attributed to the White League, which attacked Republican
officeholders to run them out of office. The paramilitary groups intimidated
and terrorized freedmen to keep them from the polls, and by the late 1870s,
conservative [Democrats](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(United_States\) "Democratic
Party \(United States\)") had retaken political control of the state.

### Great
Raft[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red_River_of_the_South&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Great Raft")]

Main article: [Great Raft](/wiki/Great_Raft "Great Raft")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Red_River_Texas.jpg/220px-
Red_River_Texas.jpg)](/wiki/File:Red_River_Texas.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Red_River_Texas.jpg "Enlarge")

Red River, Texas

In the early 19th century, settlers found that much of the river's length in
[Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana "Louisiana") was unnavigable because of a
collection of fallen trees that formed a "Great Raft" over 160 miles (260 km)
long. Captain [Henry Miller Shreve](/wiki/Henry_Miller_Shreve "Henry Miller
Shreve") began clearing the log jam in 1839. The log jam was not completely
cleared until the 1870s, when [dynamite](/wiki/Dynamite "Dynamite") became
available. The river was thereafter navigable, but north of
[Natchitoches](/wiki/Natchitoches,_Louisiana "Natchitoches, Louisiana") it was
restricted to small craft. Removal of the raft further connected the Red and
Atchafalaya rivers, accelerating the development of the Atchafalaya River
channel.[5]

In the 20th century, the [interest group](/wiki/Interest_group "Interest
group") known as the Red River Valley Association was formed to lobby the
[United States Congress](/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States
Congress") to make the river fully navigable between
[Alexandria](/wiki/Alexandria,_Louisiana "Alexandria, Louisiana") and
[Shreveport, Louisiana](/wiki/Shreveport,_Louisiana "Shreveport, Louisiana").
Leading supporters of the longstanding project were Louisiana
[Democratic](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(United_States\) "Democratic Party
\(United States\)") senators [Allen J. Ellender](/wiki/Allen_J._Ellender
"Allen J. Ellender"), [J. Bennett Johnston](/wiki/J._Bennett_Johnston "J.
Bennett Johnston") and [Russell B. Long](/wiki/Russell_B._Long "Russell B.
Long"), the Fourth District Congressman [Joe Waggonner](/wiki/Joe_Waggonner
"Joe Waggonner"), and the late Shreveport Mayor [Calhoun
Allen](/wiki/Calhoun_Allen "Calhoun Allen"). With the completion of the
project, a lock system constructed by the [US Army Corps of
Engineers](/wiki/US_Army_Corps_of_Engineers "US Army Corps of Engineers")
allowed navigation of [barge](/wiki/Barge "Barge") traffic as far north as
Shreveport.

### Greer County
debate[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red_River_of_the_South&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Greer County debate")]

Specialists debate whether the [North Fork](/wiki/North_Fork_Red_River "North
Fork Red River") or the [Prairie Dog Town
Fork](/wiki/Prairie_Dog_Town_Fork_Red_River "Prairie Dog Town Fork Red River")
is the true stem.[3] Because of a [cartographic](/wiki/Cartography
"Cartography") error, the land between the north and south forks was claimed
by both the state of Texas and the [United States federal
government](/wiki/United_States_federal_government "United States federal
government"). [Randolph B. Marcy](/wiki/Randolph_B._Marcy "Randolph B.
Marcy")'s expedition followed the Prairie Dog Town Fork in 1852.[3] Originally
called [Greer County, Texas](/wiki/Greer_County,_Texas "Greer County, Texas"),
the [US Supreme Court](/wiki/US_Supreme_Court "US Supreme Court") ruled that
it belonged to the United States, which at the time oversaw the [Oklahoma
Territory](/wiki/Oklahoma_Territory "Oklahoma Territory"). That territory was
later incorporated into the state of [Oklahoma](/wiki/Oklahoma "Oklahoma"),
whose southern border now follows the south fork. Today, the southern Prairie
Dog Town Fork is considered the main fork, though the North Fork is as long
and normally has a greater water flow.[3]

### 2015 Louisiana
flood[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red_River_of_the_South&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: 2015 Louisiana flood")]

In June 2015, the Red River flooded parts of northeast Texas, southwest
Arkansas, and Louisiana, from [New Boston, Texas](/wiki/New_Boston,_Texas "New
Boston, Texas"), to just south of [Alexandria,
Louisiana](/wiki/Alexandria,_Louisiana "Alexandria, Louisiana").[10]

##
Recreation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red_River_of_the_South&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Recreation")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Revised_bridge_atop_Red_River_in_LA_IMG_6337.jpg/200px-
Revised_bridge_atop_Red_River_in_LA_IMG_6337.jpg)](/wiki/File:Revised_bridge_atop_Red_River_in_LA_IMG_6337.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Revised_bridge_atop_Red_River_in_LA_IMG_6337.jpg "Enlarge")

Red River LA 2 Bridge,[11] not the [Jimmie Davis](/wiki/Jimmie_Davis "Jimmie
Davis") Bridge, atop the Red River between
[Bossier](/wiki/Bossier_Parish,_Louisiana "Bossier Parish, Louisiana") and
[Caddo](/wiki/Caddo_Parish,_Louisiana "Caddo Parish, Louisiana") parishes near
[Shreveport](/wiki/Shreveport,_Louisiana "Shreveport, Louisiana")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Pedestrian_walkway_at_Red_River%2C_Alexandria%2C_LA_IMG_4300.JPG/200px-
Pedestrian_walkway_at_Red_River%2C_Alexandria%2C_LA_IMG_4300.JPG)](/wiki/File:Pedestrian_walkway_at_Red_River,_Alexandria,_LA_IMG_4300.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Pedestrian_walkway_at_Red_River,_Alexandria,_LA_IMG_4300.JPG
"Enlarge")

Popular pedestrian walkway along the Red River in
[Alexandria](/wiki/Alexandria,_Louisiana "Alexandria, Louisiana"), Louisiana

In 1943, [Denison Dam](/wiki/Denison_Dam "Denison Dam") was built on the Red
River to form [Lake Texoma](/wiki/Lake_Texoma "Lake Texoma"), a large
[reservoir](/wiki/Reservoir_\(water\) "Reservoir \(water\)") of 89,000 acres
(360 km2), some 70 miles (110 km) north of [Dallas](/wiki/Dallas "Dallas").
Other reservoirs on the river's [tributaries](/wiki/Tributary "Tributary")
serve as [flood control](/wiki/Flood_control "Flood control").
